title: Race condition after setting host name causes "up" to fail.
body:
A race condition in the rename host procedure causes the provisioning to fail.
This is a specific case of the error described in issue #9356. I've created a separate case because the cause of #9356 is somewhat ambiguous and is likely caused by more than one scenario. This case only deals with errors caused while waiting for a reboot after renaming the machine during a provisioning of a Windows guest.

### Vagrant version
Vagrant 2.1.5

### Host operating system
Windows 10 Pro Version 1803 Build 17134.286

### Guest operating system
Windows 7 Enterprise with SP1

###Provider
Hyper-V


### Vagrantfile

```ruby
# -*- mode: ruby -*-
# vi: set ft=ruby :

Vagrant.configure("2") do |config|
  config.vm.box = "win7-sc-base"
  config.vm.box_url = "#{INTERNAL_VAGRANT_SHARE}/win7-sc-base.json"
  
  config.vm.define "kiosk1" do |kiosk1|
    kiosk1.vm.hostname = "VM-Kiosk1"
  end #kiosk1

  config.vm.network "public_network"

  config.vm.provider :hyperv do |v, override|
    v.memory = 2048
    v.cpus = 2
    v.ip_address_timeout = 130
    v.differencing_disk = true
    v.enable_virtualization_extensions = true
    v.vm_integration_services = {
      guest_service_interface: true,
      heartbeat: true,
      key_value_pair_exchange: true,
      shutdown: true,
      time_synchronization: true,
      vss: true
    }
  end #hyperv

  # timeout of waiting for image to stop running - may be a deprecated setting
  config.windows.halt_timeout = 20
 
  config.vm.guest = :windows
  config.vm.communicator = "winrm"

  config.winrm.username = "REDACTED"
  config.winrm.password = "REDACTED"
  config.winrm.transport = :negotiate
end
```

### Debug output
[Log 1: PowerShellError](https://gist.github.com/General-Fault/4579642973c9722d37601744f8203a41)
[Log 2: ExecutionError](https://gist.github.com/General-Fault/5a77aac61f8dffddf4dc0ce9ecabe963).


### Expected behavior
Provisioning a VM with a `vm.hostname` parameter should not fail. 

### Actual behavior
Occasionally the reboot occurs more quickly that Vagrant can start the reboot listener. As a result the provisioning script fails.

### Steps to reproduce
1. Create a VagrantFile for a Windows guest with a Hyper-V provider.
2. Add config.vm.hostname = "new-hostname" to the VagrantFile
3. On a Windows 10 host, "up" the guest.

4. As part of the provision process, the rename operation schedules a reboot with a 5 second delay.
```
[10:28:48.628] DEBUG winrmshell: [WinRM] Command created for $computer = Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_ComputerSystem
$retval = $computer.rename("new-hostname").returnvalue
if ($retval -eq 0) {
shutdown /r /t 5 /f /d p:4:1 /c "Vagrant Rename Computer"
}
exit $retval
```

Immediately after, it attempts to wait for the reboot
```
            if machine.guest.capability?(:wait_for_reboot)
                machine.guest.capability(:wait_for_reboot)
```

If the wait_for_reboot step process takes more than 5 seconds to initialize, as it often does, this call can fail.

5. If the guest is successfully provisioned, repeat the test until the provision fails.

### Details
The error is usually a `VagrantPlugins::HyperV::Errors::PowerShellError` with the message "Failed to determine IP address". [detail](https://gist.github.com/General-Fault/4579642973c9722d37601744f8203a41) 
However the race can fail at later steps and generate other errors. At least one other observed instance resulted in a `VagrantPlugins::CommunicatorWinRM::Errors::ExecutionError` [detail](https://gist.github.com/General-Fault/5a77aac61f8dffddf4dc0ce9ecabe963).

In instances where the provisioning is successful, the next get-ipaddress occurs within that 5 seconds. In instances where the provisioning fails, that time is longer (or I suspect Windows is taking longer to shutdown). The IP address check seems to be a part of asking windows for a shutdown event. So it's just late.

### Workaround
A workaround is to increase the delay to 15 seconds (in Vagrant\embedded\gems\2.1.5\gems\vagrant-2.1.5\plugins\guests\windows\cap\change_host_name.rb:20 - see below). But I think that a better solution here would be to assume that a failed IP address meant that the system had already started the shutdown, and continue normally.

          script = <<-EOH
            $computer = Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_ComputerSystem
            $retval = $computer.rename("#{name}").returnvalue
            if ($retval -eq 0) {
              shutdown /r /t 15 /f /d p:4:1 /c "Vagrant Rename Computer"
            }
            exit $retval
          EOH


### References
See also issue #9356.
